title: If the age of exploration did not happen, who would have discovered America? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A, Ozo. Leif Erikson, as Antonina Pereguda so elegantly pointed out, discovered Newfoundland. Leif was the son of Erik the Red himself a truly interesting Viking! Leif went that far West after hearing reports from other Vikings who’d strayed. Leif attempted to found a settlement but it failed. See the chapter titled “Discovering Vinland! Leif Erikson - Wikipedia I saw in the notes a Norwegian discovered the settlement’s ruins in 1960. Now to Columbus: He did not set out to discover the New World; he was looking for a trade route that was faster and less life-threatening than having to round the Cape of Good Hope.  So his “discovery was an accident. In fact, Columbus believed the indigenous people he encountered to be Indians living on an island away from the Indian Subcontinent. That’s why Native Americans were saddled with the label American Indians. The point of all this being somebody would have happened upon it sooner or later. It might have been anyone!

… You mean if the world just ended before the 15th century? Or do you mean that it happened differently than in our history and someone else reported the existence of the Americas to Europe? I mean, presuming that Europe is still a thing. Even if the entire world didn’t end, maybe Europe as such doesn’t exist by the time anyone gets around to trying to tell them about the Americas. You’ve offered not the slightest hint of why the Age of Exploration didn’t happen. It could be anything from the entire universe just suffering a random total existential failure or later historians deciding to call it the Age of Expansion or Age of Exploitation instead (or just not coming up with a particular name for it). One of these things is a bit more plausible and doesn’t change anything that actually happened other than how history books referred to it later.
